Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: DataHub - A Collaborative Dataset Management Platform for Data Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rise of the Internet, smart phones, and wireless sensors has resulted in a vast trove of data about all aspects of our lives, from our social interactions to our personal preferences to our vital signs and medical records. Increasingly, "data science" teams want to collaboratively analyze these datasets, to understand trends and to extract actionable business, scientific, or social insights. Unfortunately, while there exist tools to support data analysis, much-needed underlying infrastructure and data management capabilities are missing. To this end, "DataHub", a collaborative platform for cleaning, storing, understanding, sharing, and publishing datasets, will be developed. DataHub will be a publicly accessible platform that will host private user datasets as well as public datasets retrieved from online sources. DataHub will serve as the common substrate for data science, freeing up end users from tedious dataset book-keeping tasks, and instead supporting them in their search for useful insights. DataHub will be deployed on a large scale at MIT; partnerships with organizations and groups from a variety of sectors will be leveraged upon to show benefits for real data scientists and to ensure that the proposed techniques meet real-world big data challenges. The curriculum development part of this project will lead to the training of new data scientists, and the project will also provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to participate in research and learn how to do collaborative research.

Unlike most systems that focus on improving performance or on supporting even more sophisticated analyses, DataHub will instead focus on simplifying and automating many fundamental book-keeping operations that are a pre-requisite to data science. Key features of DataHub will include: (1) a flexible, source code control-like versioning system for data, that efficiently branches, merges, and differences datasets; (2) new data ingest, cleaning, and wrangling tools designed to automate data cleaning process; (3) the ability to search for "related" tables and to integrate them into the analysis process; and (4) the ability to selectively share and collaborate on data sets across users and teams. Overall, DataHub will significantly reduce the amount of effort involved on the part of data scientists for preparing, analyzing, sharing, and managing data.

For more information, see the project website at: http://data-hub.org

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rise of the Internet, smart phones, and wireless sensors has resulted in a vast trove of data about all aspects of our lives, from our social interactions to our personal preferences to our vital signs and medical records. Increasingly, ``data science'' teams want to collect, clean, structure, store, and collaboratively analyze these datasets, to understand trends and to extract actionable business or social insights. Unfortunately, while there exist tools to support data analysis, much-needed underlying infrastructure and data management capabilities are missing. The goal of this project was to build infrastructure for cleaning, storing, and understanding datasets.
The key outcomes of this project can be summarized as follows. We developed platforms and algorithms for sharing datasets (Datahub) as well as searching for and discovering datasets that may be useful for analysis (Aurum and Data Civilizer). We built systems and techniques for storing, retrieving, and querying data versions for the structured (Decibel and Orpheus) and unstructured (RStore, DEX, ProvDB) dataset settings, trading off storage and query latencies, and developed a new query language for querying across data versions (VQuel). We developed techniques for dataset compression (Squish), as well as comparing datasets for differences (Data Diff). We developed mechanisms for cleaning datasets automatically (Datamaran). We developed data management systems for machine learning, tailored towards model management (ModelDB and ModelHub) as well as the end-to-end iterative process (Helix). Overall, by developing crucial infrastructure for supporting the sharing, versioning, storing, collaborating, cleaning, querying, and learning process on large collections of datasets, we have made present-day data science more effortless, effective, and efficient.
The major results from this project were published in leading conferences and journals in the field of databases, formed major parts of multiple dissertations of students at all three universities, and were the subject of several invited talks. The project was also instrumental in training multiple PhD and undergraduate students each at Illinois, Maryland, and MIT to conduct research -- the students have gained skills in conducting research, software engineering skills, and experience and knowledge in working on real-world problems in managing collaborative data science. Six of these students have graduated over the last year and are currently employed in industry and academic research and development labs, such as Visa Research, Amazon Web Services, and Google. One student founded a company, Instabase, on topics related to this project, with 10s of millions of dollars of venture capital funding to date.


Last Modified: 02/03/2020
Modified by: Samuel Madden
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The rise of the Internet, smart phones, and wireless sensors has resulted in a vast trove of data about all aspects of our lives, from our social interactions to our personal preferences to our vital signs and medical records. Increasingly, ``data science'' teams want to collect, clean, structure, store, and collaboratively analyze these datasets, to understand trends and to extract actionable business or social insights. Unfortunately, while there exist tools to support data analysis, much-needed underlying infrastructure and data management capabilities are missing. The goal of this project was to build infrastructure for cleaning, storing, and understanding datasets. The key outcomes of this project can be summarized as follows. We developed platforms and algorithms for sharing datasets (Datahub) as well as searching for and discovering datasets that may be useful for analysis (Aurum and Data Civilizer). We built systems and techniques for storing, retrieving, and querying data versions for the structured (Decibel and Orpheus) and unstructured (RStore, DEX, ProvDB) dataset settings, trading off storage and query latencies, and developed a new query language for querying across data versions (VQuel). We developed techniques for dataset compression (Squish), as well as comparing datasets for differences (Data Diff). We developed mechanisms for cleaning datasets automatically (Datamaran). We developed data management systems for machine learning, tailored towards model management (ModelDB and ModelHub) as well as the end-to-end iterative process (Helix). Overall, by developing crucial infrastructure for supporting the sharing, versioning, storing, collaborating, cleaning, querying, and learning process on large collections of datasets, we have made present-day data science more effortless, effective, and efficient. The major results from this project were published in leading conferences and journals in the field of databases, formed major parts of multiple dissertations of students at all three universities, and were the subject of several invited talks. The project was also instrumental in training multiple PhD and undergraduate students each at Illinois, Maryland, and MIT to conduct research -- the students have gained skills in conducting research, software engineering skills, and experience and knowledge in working on real-world problems in managing collaborative data science. Six of these students have graduated over the last year and are currently employed in industry and academic research and development labs, such as Visa Research, Amazon Web Services, and Google.
